title: Friday, 8th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Sigh.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
BE11:07am

OB1 Happy 159th day of the year
Soundbuy Morning all
BE11:08am

Switching it on and off worked though, so we're here.

Flaneur Retail-pocalypse is back on!?!?!
11:08 am
BE11:08am

And there's an inevitability about today's portrait.

Excel Developer More negative European economic news today. Europe heading for recession in my opinion.
Soundbuy That qualifies you as a systems engineer....
OB1 ha! still looking for a copy of that report
BE11:08am

andyalan10 Thought portrait might be Geordie Greg, too media, not enough finance?
wayneJ Ah - I am on time
BE11:09am

Gavin Patterson. Picture's from this here 2013 profile, which outline's BT's plans to go toe-to-toe against Sky and throw money at TV.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

https://www.ft.com...-bf32-00144feabdc0

BE11:11am

A plan that attracted a certain degree of cynicism from the start, it has to be said.

Flaneur I thought it was Oliver Kamm. But theres no reason he'd be in the news or under scrutiny by the media.....
BE11:12am

And now, a mere day after Amazon further balkanised the football market, Mr Patterson is shoved out the door.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

https://www.ft.com...-b6eb-4acfcfb08c11

BE11:13am

So ...... what's gone on here?

BE11:13am

Is is normal for a CEO to be dumped just a month and a couple of days after he sets out a fairly ambitious looking strategy rejig?

Lawro Bring us some opinion from Saeed Baradar of Louis Capital.
11:13 am
BE11:13am

And, perhaps more importantly, commits the company to no dividend cut for two years?

BE11:14am

Statement goes today that BT's board remains supportive of the new strategy

Paper Chase Yeah! Baradar! Or is he still under the Mifid II kosh?
SupposeToBeWorking... Hi all
BE11:14am

(@ROTR: Saeed's out of the market currently. Soz.)

11:15 am
BE11:15am

All of which leaves Mr Patterson's replacement's boxed in, pretty much. Not a lot his successor can do.

BornCynic Morning - cruel to switch the hamster on / off BE. You'll confuse the poor thing............
Paper Chase Well, on the bright side, price is up a sparkling one tenth of one per cent.
BE11:16am

.... except talk nicely to Ofcom and wind down the TV investment a bit, which'll need to be done over multiple years because that's the way subs work.

BE11:16am

UBS puts the job app for the next guy as:

11:16 am
BE11:17am

[address] the pace of FTTH rollout at Openreach; the strategy around BT Sport; the future of Global Services; execution of the Transformation programme and how much of the £1.5bn pa of cost savings should be re-invested back into the business.

BE11:17am

So -- no kitchen sink.

BE11:17am

CEO change brings the risk that estimates could be rebased. However, BT has already pulled down expectations post Q4 results and we think the guidance is conservative and leaves some headroom for Openreach to accelerate its fibre (FTTH) rollout

Soundbuy BT must have a pension thingy........
11:18 am
BE11:18am

All of which means the change of management's simply a change of personality. Dumping Patterson means getting a new face for shareholder meetings, and for Ofcom meetings, and in Whitehall.

Pharma @Soundbuy, wasn't it the other way round? The BT pension has a legacy telephone company.
BE11:19am

Here's Jefferies.

BE11:19am

It seems highly unlikely to us that this signals near-term risk to forecasts and BT has not updated on the outlook in this morning's statement. Instead, we believe the decision reflects adverse shareholder reaction to BT's results last month and Patterson's leadership. The potential positive now, in our view, is that his departure may ease bottlenecks in discussions with Ofcom as BT seeks a fair bet regulatory settlement on fibre.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

And Macquarie.

Soundbuy Ahhh............is that the case.......
BE11:20am

We believe Mr Patterson has paid the price for his losing battle with Ofcom over Openreach and failure to recognise the investment tide was moving against BT’s previous cash flow targets. BT was over-earning in 2014 and 2015 and the Openreach and Ofcom battle was one that BT could not win. Regulation of entry level FTTc was inevitable and greater separation of Openreach recognised a theme across the industry as networks are upgraded into FTTp.

BE11:21am

Then there's some stuff about Premier rights inflation staying benign and etc, albeit with this interesting wee line ......

11:21 am
BE11:22am

[O]ur greatest fear for the UK market is should Amazon resell FTTp connectivity with its Prime TV offer. This would upset the current market structure more substantially.

BE11:23am

There were reports in 2016, if memory serves, that Amazon was looking at becoming an internet provider in Europe.

BE11:23am

The Information, which is usually on the money, suggested it: https://www.theinf...t-service-offering

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Reviving that plan would be somewhat exciting for the sector.

Paper Chase Is Deutsche still interested in BT?
Excel Developer @BE: vertical integration from Amazon TV, cool.
undefined
nichoman Lot of chatter about European banking mergers at moment....BarChart / UniSocGen / DeutscheCommerz. Recokon any of it will happen ?
BE11:25am

In terms of the wider picture -- down.

Excel Developer #EMFX Rout : I'm glad I sold my South Africa stocks earlier this year.
11:26 am
BE11:27am

Everything, pretty much. Down. With miners leading it.

Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 1,238, down 61.5 (-4.73%), High: 1,295, Low: 1,237, Volume: 473.55k
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 1,096, down 39 (-3.44%), High: 1,166, Low: 1,095, Volume: 1.01m
Shrink Everything down.
11:27 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 384.27, down 9.78 (-2.48%), High: 391.00, Low: 384.25, Volume: 9.40m
Shrink Isn't that a Yellowcard song?
Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 995.40, down 80.6 (-7.49%), High: 1,059, Low: 994.00, Volume: 1.13m
DRichi There was a Paul Johnson song 20 years ago
BE11:30am

Now, we'll head back to the sector in a moment, but Kaz is interesting.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

It's underperforming largely because of a Cazenove downgrade.

BE11:32am

But the Cazenove downgrade is largely on the risk that Kaz buys Baimskaya, the big Russian copper-gold thing it confirmed it was keen on in February.

DogsEars INMARSAT - any ideas?
BE11:32am

However, Kaz today sold nearly 20% of the Koksay copper development in Kazakhstan to a Chinese thing with a very long name.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

( China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Company Ltd)

Soundbuy Must have huge business cards.......
BE11:34am

That's a pretty clear indication that Koksay will get developed, meaning Kaz probably can't afford Baimskaya without scrapping its debt paydown.

Div @DRichi ..... tune!!
BE11:35am

But then -- Bloomberg reported earlier in the week that Kaz was still fancying Baimskaya for $1bn so who knows?

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Anyway, back to Caz. Sector note, conveniently.

BE11:36am

JPM Commodities Research predict a bullish outlook for commodities in 2018, due to accelerating and aligned global growth, US$ weakness and rising inflation. Our colleagues’ analysis across the last five US economic
cycles since 1960 concludes commodity prices typically move higher
during the last 20% of an expansion. Our colleagues expect above trend
global growth to stretch into 2019 and JPM FX Strategists expect DXY
to weaken ~2% to 92 by YE’18.

BE11:36am

Mining valuations have re-rated but remain attractive: UK
diversified share prices are +30% on average since start of Dec’17. As a
result, average 2018/19E FCF yields have re-rated from 14%/15% to
10%/12%. Average mark to market 2018/19 EV/EBITDA has re-rated
from 4.2x/3.8x to 4.9x/4.4x. Attractive valuations are still evident; Anglo
American’s 8.2x PER and 3.8x EV/EBITDA (2019E mark to market)
screen at a 20-25% discount to BHP and RIO. Glencore's 6.0x PER and
3.9x EV/EBITDA screen at a 40%/25% discount. FCF for the sector
remains attractive and can support growing cash returns across 2018-19.
We calculate spot commodity prices will need to fall 20-25% before the
UK diversifieds fall to the ~5% FCF yield of the wider market.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Raise LT iron ore price to $60/t, coking coal to $140/t, thermal to
$77/t: We have undertaken a detailed analysis of incentive prices across
iron ore and coal. We raise our LT iron ore price by 20% to $60/t
reflecting: “value over volume” management strategies make us more
optimistic on long-term supply restraint, plus we assess 90 th percentile
marginal cost at $60/t and elasticity of Chinese domestic supply at
greater than $80/t. We raise our LT coking coal price to $140/t ($110/t previous) and thermal coal to $77/t ($67/t previous).

BE11:37am

In terms of stocks:

Excel Developer Geordie Greig is the new editor of the Daily Mail. He used to edit the Mail on Sunday (MoS). MoS was in favour of Remain. I wonder what will happen.
Tom Dalgleish Gladys Stokes used to do star alignment
BE11:38am

We remain OW Anglo American and Glencore with both trading at greater than 20% discounts vs peers, we remain Neutral Rio Tinto and BHP. We raise our LT iron ore price to $60/t and thermal coal to $77/t, benefiting all UK diversifieds. We d/g KAZ to Neutral and Anglo Platinum to UW, citing a
bleak outlook for platinum. JPM Commodities Research expect a
resumption of a medium term trend lower for US$ and a ~10% higher gold
price – we u/g Randgold to OW after a ~15% share price fall YTD and
cite AngloGold and Gold Fields (both OW) as exceptionally cheap on 3-
4x EV/EBITDA in 2018/19.

11:37 am
undefined
Excel Developer EM rout: https://twitter.com/FerroTV/status/1005030489768460288
BE11:39am

Inmarsat mentioned on the right. It's mentioned most Fridays so that's not a surprise.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 427.48, up 9.88 (+2.37%), High: 429.30, Low: 411.20, Volume: 1.46m
Soundbuy Well, I haven't mentioned Smurfit today......
nichoman IWG deadline today ?
Dec69 - Skeptic re: Kaz 'allegedly' there's two execs that have fallen in love with Baimskaya. Whether true or not, they should scrap the deal just on cost/debt.
11:41 am
BE11:41am

We flagged up vague talk around Inmarsat this time last month, and repeatedly before that. EchoStar and Softbank/OneWeb are the obvious candidates.

Pele ISAT LN Ligado Networks apparently told investor last week it thinks FCC approval is imminent after latest power reduction
BE11:42am

You've also got the Ligado Networks FCC approval thing as a binary. To remind, Ligado cash will end in 2019 without approval,

BE11:43am

Here's the latest FCC submission from Ligado saying they can cut power requirements by 99%: https://ecfsapi.fc...53120688074/Ligado License Modification Cover Letter and Amendment (5-31-2018).pdf

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Hang on, I'll shortlink that.

Dec69 - Skeptic The same as with IntelSat in the US, it looks as though the 'drama' about C SPAN is being utilised to strengthen balance sheets whilst investors pray/hope on some jam tomorrow.
BE11:44am

https://bit.ly/2kC9S3L (PDF)

BE11:44am

Bear in mind however that the Ligado vs GPS fight has been going on for a decade.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And it's them versus The Air Force Space Command.

Pharma You have to be suspicious of a technology company when they say "oh, hang on, that number we told you is 100x too high".
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE remember the questions about RPC Group last month, seems the company's health/prospects are being doubted by the market a little more.
BE11:45am

Here's Morgan Stanley to recap.

BE11:46am

[Inmarsat] Management has flagged well in advance that there could be a pause in payments from Ligado to Inmarsat in 2019 (which is built into the contract) if Ligado does not get FCC approval. Hence, consensus forecasts payments going from $130mn in 2018 to zero in 2019. However, these payments would presumably be back on if Ligado can secure FCC approval. The Inmarsat-Ligado agreement is for payments of $130mn pa growing at 3% for 97 years, which we calculate to have an NPV of c$1.25bn to Inmarsat, which is worth c200p/ share.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

The shares are particularly volatile, but we see significant upside on successfully monetising spectrum in the US. However, the core business is seeing some near-term challenges, particularly in maritime (competition, macro) and aviation (weak profitability). The shares trade on 20x 2019e P/E vs satellite peers SES at 21x and Eutelsat at 13x.

BE11:47am

And UBS, in a sector wrap out overnight.

BE11:47am

We are in line with consensus at c$450m for Inmarsat's 2018E Maritime EBITDA (c70% of group EBITDA), but believe there could be downside to Maritime estimates if Iridium looks to push its new product, Iridium Certus, in H2 2018.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Could Ligado Networks and M&A lead to greater than 240p upside or greater than 60p downside for Inmarsat? Yes. In our base case we value long-term Ligado cash payments at 60p (20% probability), but this could move towards 300p or 0p if the FCC approves or denies Ligado Networks' use of the spectrum Inmarsat supplies. Reported M&A risk from Echostar and Softbank/OneWeb remains, but is also likely to depend on visibility on how the supply side of the industry develops.

BE11:48am

So there we are.

undefined
Dec69 - Skeptic so a range or 0-300 pence range.
11:50 am
BE11:51am

Soooooooooooooooooo ............. what else?

Tom Dalgleish Uranium seems to be stirring. Anyone?
Pharma @BE any more colour on the KS & DK SocGen LIBOR story from yesterday?Strange the DoJ didn't go for the jugular, if they thought instructions came from the top.
Gross Loydman Anything on Petropavlovsk? Big move since yesterday
BE11:52am

(@Pharma: because Kadhim's now on another continent and in another timezone, I do not. Sorry.)

Dec69 - Skeptic Games workshop? Trading update?
BE11:52am

POG mentioned.

11:52 am
Petropavlovsk PLC (POG:LSE): Last: 7.97, up 0.87 (+12.25%), High: 8.20, Low: 7.11, Volume: 11.98m
Dec69 - Skeptic @pharma I think there's more to come on the SocGen story.
BE11:53am

It's a bloody silly story, particularly if you have a bad memory for names ending in "a".

BE11:54am

Today's update from POG on the identity of CABS Platform gives us five names.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Evgeny Khata
Viktoriya Grynova
Erika Gordisheva
Yulia Mangusheva
Mikhail Volkov

nichoman I thought POG shenanigans were all about old board trying to get back in ?
BE11:55am

Plus Nikolai Lioustiger and Viktoriya Grynova with limited powers of attorney.

BE11:55am

But ....

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The Board does not believe these individuals are the ultimate owners behind CABS. Unfortunately, this disclosure seems to be yet another veil of secrecy, and we expect there are further layers to be peeled back before the true identity of the controlling person(s) is revealed. The Board continues to be mystified by the extraordinary lengths at which the requisitioners are going to conceal the true source of control behind these offshore shell vehicles that invested only three months ago. This secrecy should raise several concerns for shareholders ahead of the Annual General Meeting on 29 June 2018.

Mouselet two viktoriya grynovas?
Pharma @Dec69, I got the impression that the fine settled the matter. Seems out of character for the US authorities to let them off with a slap on the wrist. Trump / Macron love-in perhaps?
Mouselet Macron's remarks about G7+1 suggest that the affair might be over
Dec69 - Skeptic There's a thought @Pharma
BE11:56am

A reminder that this group owns 4.55% of POG

Shrink Nobody mentions Daily Mail?
Shrink And MOS, of course.
BE11:57am

But also have support of Kenges Rakishev, 22% holder.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Here's Neil's update: https://www.ft.com...-b6eb-4acfcfb08c11

BE11:57am

And beyond that very carefully written story, we're probably best not speculating.

undefined
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR - enjoy the weekend
Gross Loydman Thanks BE
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Hey ROTR, you're in a London-centric media bubble. No one other than a few old hacks in the Prince of Wales cares about who does what at newspapers.

Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 677.50, down 2.5 (-0.37%), High: 679.00, Low: 674.50, Volume: 115.32k
Pharma I have no sympathy if you invest in russian companies and then worry about your investment.
Alchemy30 IWG - extension it is then
BE12:01pm

Least of all investors, who seem to see the dead paper side of DMGT as an inconvenience at most.

Blank canvas I wonder what Otter is doing this weekend
Excel Developer @BE: what is revenue split between paper and web then?
Soundbuy Bon w/end to both sides..........cheers
Soundbuy Otter is doing interesting plans.......
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

More relevant to our interests:

BE12:02pm

https://www.invest...1806081200017992Q/

BE12:03pm

Discussions remain ongoing with Starwood and TDR and in accordance with Rule 2.6(c) of the Code, the Board of IWG requested that the Panel on Takeovers and Mergers (the "Panel") extend the deadline referred to above with respect to these parties to enable continued discussions regarding the Possible Offers. Accordingly, an extension has been granted by the Panel and each of Starwood and TDR must, by no later than 5.00 p.m. on 29 June 2018, either announce a firm intention to make an offer for IWG in accordance with Rule 2.7 of the Code or announce that it does not intend to make an offer, in which case the announcement will be treated as a statement to which Rule 2.8 of the Code applies. This deadline will only be extended with the consent of the Panel.

A further announcement will be made when appropriate. There can be no certainty that any offer will be made for the Company, nor as to the terms on which any offer might be made.

12:02 pm
IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 314.40, up 0.4 (+0.13%), High: 316.10, Low: 311.60, Volume: 654.19k
BE12:03pm

Not a huge surprise.

Okay, that'll do for Friday. Thanks for joining.
